title: 109_s3514
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Social Security Number Online Protection Act of 2006". Congress finds that the inappropriate display of social security numbers has led to various illegal activities, impacting interstate commerce and public safety. The government mandates social security numbers for tax purposes, benefits eligibility, and employment. The government mandates social security numbers for tax purposes, benefits eligibility, and employment, leading to unintended consequences such as facilitating crime, fraud, and privacy invasions. It is necessary for the Federal Government to take steps to prevent the abuse of social security account numbers. The Federal Government needs to address the abuse of social security account numbers by individuals exempting themselves from requirements. State and local laws make public documents containing social security numbers available, increasing the risk of misuse. The online availability of public records stored by official repositories increases the risk of social security account numbers being widely displayed and misused. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON DISPLAYING LAST 4 DIGITS OF SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT NUMBERS ONLINE BY STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS. Amend Title 18, U.S. Code to prohibit the public display of the last 4 digits of social security numbers by state and local governments on the internet. Prohibition on displaying last 4 digits of social security account numbers online by State and local governments. State and local governments are prohibited from displaying the last 4 digits of any social security account number on the internet. This rule does not override any existing restrictions on displaying social security numbers online. The section outlines penalties for states or political subdivisions that do not comply with the prohibition on displaying social security numbers online. The Attorney General can impose a civil penalty of up to $5,000 per day for substantial noncompliance. The Attorney General may enforce penalties of up to $5,000 per day for substantial noncompliance with the prohibition on displaying social security numbers online. ``Sec. 2734. Definitions
    ``In this chapter:
            ``(1) Display to the general public on the internet.--
                    ``(A) In general.--The term `display to the general 
                public on the Internet' means, in connection with all, 
                or any part of, a social security account number, to 
                place such number or any part of such number in a 
                viewable manner on an Internet site that is available 
                to the general public, including any Internet site that 
                requires a fee for access to information accessible on

A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts in the United States Code. SEC. 4. Grants to state and local governments to comply with the prohibition on displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers on the internet. Effective immediately for violations after enactment. The Attorney General will award grants to States and political subdivisions to remove or redact the last 4 digits of social security numbers from public internet displays to comply with federal law. The Attorney General will award grants to States and political subdivisions to remove or redact social security numbers from public internet displays. States or political subdivisions must submit an application for a grant, and $10,000,000 is authorized for each of fiscal years 2007 and 2008. In fiscal years 2007 and 2008, $10,000,000 is authorized for grants to States and political subdivisions to remove social security numbers from public internet displays. The term "State" includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, and the Northern Marianas.
